New York University Archives
Records of the Office of the Registrar
New York University. Office of the Registrar
Tompkins, Leslie J. (Leslie Jay), 1867-1952
Stevenson, John J. (John James), 1841-1924
Ladue, Pomeroy
RG.12.4
4.4 Linear Feet in 18 custom boxes
1832-1916 The Office of the Registrar is responsible for the integrity of academic policies, the student information system and student records from application to degree conferral. The office works to protect and preserve the academic records of New York University's students and to provide a framework for students to navigate the academic process. The Records of the Office of the Registrar consist of 18 handwritten ledgers dating between 1832 and 1916. The majority of the ledgers track applications for admission, student matriculation, class rolls, grades, and citations for meritorious conduct. Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date (if known); Records of the Office of the Registrar; RG 12.4; box number; folder number; New York University Archives, New York University.
Scope and Contents
The Records of the Office of the Registrar comprise handwritten ledgers dating between 1832 and 1916. The majority of the ledgers track applications for admission, student matriculation, class rolls, grades, and citations for meritorious conduct. A scrapbook compiled by the college's first registrar, Leslie J. Tompkins, documents the construction of and repairs to several buildings on the Heights Campus; endowments, scholarships, and prizes granted to students; commencement and lecture programs; and annual reports from the Treasurer's and the Registrar's offices. One volume lists officers and platoons, possibly in an early campus security organization; roll calls and lists of officers sent on patrol; and entries documenting arrests. One volume consists of a letterbook, containing letters written by J. J. Stevenson as registrar and Pomeroy Ladue as secretary regarding admission, coursework, and commencement in the graduate school in the 1890s.
Arrangement
This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Conditions Governing Use
Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by the Office of the Registrar are maintained by New York University. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from the University Archives. Please contact university-archives@nyu.edu.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Materials found in collection; there is no documentation concerning the provenance of these materials. The accession numbers associated with this collection are 90.020 and 2019.113.
Processing Information
Decisions regarding arrangement, description, and physical interventions for this collection prior to 2019 are unknown. In 2019 some of the materials were placed in new acid-free custom boxes.
